content:
I've rearranged various sentences in Goal section for a smoother logical flow.

I've removed the last two constraints as they're not constraints, and they've been mentioned in Goal section.

I've replaced the tags "Permutations" and "Combinations" with "Tiling". Permutations and combinations primarily deal with ordering or selecting elements from a set, typically involving counting different arrangements. They are the main focus here, since this puzzle is about whether it is possible to cover a space rather than counting possibilities.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle and very clear description.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle with good description :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very well made puzzle with interesting problem to solve. Clear statement with example. Good job.

Nice puzzle, I have got much of fun playing it.

Pracalculated all possible inputs and found out that one forth of of them gives "NOT POSSIBLE".

What should be corrected in statement:

Make space before Example to separate it a bit

in Note 2 '(more than a wall with different dimensions)' need some corection, more than one? Also It's easy to understand without this in round bracked.

'The wall height must be two inches or more (two rows of blocks pieces at minimum).' and under this there is Note1 which tells the same. Note1 is not necessary

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hello, just my opinion, I think it should be explicitly said that the pieces can't be stack vertically (else the puzzle make no sense but still, I feel it should be be written). 
a 1x3 can't be used as 
□
□
□ 
only □□□
Not saying it implies every player knows LEGO. 

Also, did you check if LEGO can be used by a company like CodinGame ? is it a trademark name ?

Hi, are you sure of your validators
25 inches samples TEST

-3- 1 1
-3- 1 1
-3- | |
-3- 3 3
-3- | |

isn't that a wall according to rules? Or did I miss something?
Have a good day.

I just checked whether x1 + 2.x2 + 3.x3 is a rectangular number (e.g. n*m with n,m integers). 
It made all tests pass, but I am not sure it is actually true.

Good work. It looks much better now.

Further improvement may be:
1. clever use of Styles (bold, yellow highlight, etc) in formatting. For reference, see how other puzzle statements are presented.
2. duplication of several lines in statement and input can be avoided
3. Prefer to have more sets of test cases.  For binary answers, it takes only 2^4 random trials in average to pass 4 validators. To prevent blind guesses, refer to some of my puzzles that each test case is composed of multiple tests.
4. I doubt is the max limit 30 too lenient. Can a reasonable code handle a hundred or even a thousand blocks? I haven't done the coding so this is just a guess.
Hi, This is my first Classic puzzle, awaiting for your criticism ;)

It is not intended to criticize. Look at it positively. It is just to point out in what ways it can be improved.

1. The current version of the statement does not read like English. lowered the effectiveness of communication. Lots of rewriting is desired.

2. Error in the Input section. All are "Line 1" ?

3. x1, x2, x3 vs onesCount, twosCount... Please keep using one naming scheme. I prefer x1, x2...

4. I did a few minutes drafting on the algorithm and found that it is not so hard. May be "Medium" is a better class.

Thanks Again,
- I ve added some styles , and tried removing the duplication, as per your recommendation.
- I ll try to enhance the testcases, also will check code performance against larger combinations, Hope you may also give a try coding the puzzle and feedback again

Good catch, It is almost the case  that the wall cant be built  when the total sum of pieces' sizes is prime.
However, this is not the case with not prime nums !  
Note, even having a prime number of one inch pieces, we can build the wall as one column (the constraint is for one row only)
I have added some more testcase, kindly check
My bad is it a vertical wall you are building, not a rectangle or square (view from above).

Thanks For feedback, I ve added the correct rule _ plz check Note #1.
For the trademark issue, i actually did not think about this legality :) but anyway i ve changed it use just term "Kids block"

Thanks for feedback, I ve applied the first two comments, 
regarding the last comment for note 1, it was requested by other players to mention this rule explicitly! so i may keep it
Thanks for approval & thanks for your kind comment
Many Thanks :)

Sorry, I did not get your point ...
For the "25 inches samples TEST"  
4X1 + 0X2 + 7X3 --> not possible
In your provided solution What do u mean by "|" ? if it means blank, So we have bottom row width =3 And second row width = 9 ! 
The problem should verify that the wall rows are all of same width

Thanks For your feedback,
I ve quoted your example to make it mre clear , Plz check Note #2

Indeed my lazy strategy now fails for a few tests (11, 13, 15).  Enough to have to think a bit more in-depth. 
In Python we are proposed x_1, x_2, x_3 as variables. Probably x1, x2, x3 would be better.

Thanks for your feedback, sure i appreciated it and took it positively

I have modified the statement (hope this will be more clear), also fixed the error & decreased the difficulty level to Medium.

Awaiting for any further comments to improve more...
